metadata.title: Peroneal Nerve Injury
anatomical location body part affected: The peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve arising from the sacral plexus, which is formed from the L4-S4  ventral rami. As the sciatic nerve traverses the posterior thigh, it bifurcates just proximal to the popliteal fossa into the tibial and common peroneal nerves(1)

The common peroneal nerve extends beyond the lateral head of the gastrocnemius and around the fibular head, where it is most superficial. After this point, the common peroneal nerve bifurcates into the superficial peroneal nerve (traversing the lateral lower leg) and the deep peroneal nerve (within the deep anterior compartment near the interosseous membrane)(1)

The deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior muscles of the lower leg responsible for ankle dorsiflexion (i.e., tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus, and peroneus tertius), whereas the superficial peroneal muscles innervate the ankle muscles responsible for eversion (i.e., peroneus longus, peroneus brevis)(1)
description: Peroneal nerve injury is the most common lower extremity mononeuropathy(2)
It involves damage to the peroneal nerve (i.e., myelin sheath or the entire neuron) that results in a loss of muscle function and sensation in the lower leg and/or foot(3)

ICD-10 codes.S84.1: injury of peroneal nerve at the lower leg level
ICD-10 codes.G57.3: lesion of lateral popliteal nerve (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Usually signs and symptoms are unilateral(4)
Decreased sensation (tingling, numbness) in lateral lower leg and foot and dorsum of foot, typically in a dermatomal pattern(4)
Pain within the lateral lower leg and foot, often in the dorsum of the foot(4)
Drop foot (i.e., weakness of the dorsiflexors and ankle evertors) usually is evident(2)
Stubbing toe, slapping foot, or tripping(4)
Antalgic gait pattern with decreased heel strike on initial contact and foot drop through the swing phase on the affected lower extremity
Decreased static and dynamic balance; increased fall risk
Difficulties with walking or climbing stairs because of foot drop(4)
contraindications precautions to test: It is important to always respect the patient’s self-reported  level of pain

Although the peroneal nerve is most susceptible to injury at the knee, the nerve can also be injured at the hip and ankle due to tethered nerve fibers that are subject to traction injuries. Thus, the hip and ankle must be assessed in addition to the knee when evaluating a patient with a peroneal nerve injury(1)

Although foot drop is most likely due to a peroneal nerve injury, it can also be caused by other conditions that an evaluating clinician should rule out.(10) It is important to conduct a thorough evaluation, including a low-back  assessment. Patients can present with a foot drop due to an L5 radiculopathy (and not from a peroneal nerve injury) without low back or radicular symptoms.(10) See Rule out , below –Acute compartment syndrome is a medical emergency requiring immediate surgery. For more information,see Clinical Review…Compartment Syndrome, Acute ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708485. Chronic compartment syndrome is not a medical emergency. For more information, see Clinical Review…Compartment Syndrome, Chronic ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708750.

causes: Acute trauma to lateral side of knee/fibular head(5)–Contact sports (e.g., ice hockey player hit with stick or puck; football collision)(6)–Gunshot wound(7)–Fracture of fibular head/lateral tibial plateau(6)–Knee dislocation(8)-Common peroneal nerve injury occurs in 10–40%  of knee dislocations–Lacerations(1)–Posterolateral corner injury(28)

Acute iatrogenic–Overly tight plaster cast(1)–Below-knee  ankle brace(1)–Ice-pack  wrap over nerve(9)–Obstetric stirrups(10)–Direct surgical injury(11)-In rare cases, common peroneal nerve injury (CPNI) can occur after cardiothoracic surgery in adults(21)-Lisfranc surgery and hardware removal(29)-Reconstruction for multi-ligament  knee injuries(30)-Acetabular fracture and reconstruction(31)-Mechanism of injury appears to be direct compression of the peroneal nerve during hip retraction-Knee flexion reduced stretch and pressure to the nerve-Total knee arthroplasty(32)-Injury to the common peroneal nerve occurred in 0.4% of 47,585 knee replacements-Fasciotomy for anterior chronic exertional compartment syndrome (CECS)(33)-Although up to 8% of patients receiving a fasciotomy experience symptoms suggestive of iatrogenic superficialperoneal neve injury, a case series and cadaveric study determined there was no risk of nerve injury in a semiblindfasciotomy for anterior CECS
Habitual conduction block–Habitual leg-crossing(10)–Sitting cross-legged(10)–Tight-fitting  high boots–Constricting knee band–Prolonged squatting or kneeling(10)-Can result in bilateral symptoms(22)
Anterior or lateral compartment syndrome(10)–Can be an acute or chronic injury
Traction injury–Severe lateral ankle sprain may lead to overstretching of the superficial peroneal nerve(10)–Varus knee deformity from osteoarthritis(1)–Rarely, a rapid growth spurt(23)
Masses/tumors(10)–Nerve sheath tumors–Lipomas–Ganglion cysts–Popliteal cysts–Fibular tumors–Osteomas–Hematomas–Intraneural cysts–Perineural cysts

Side effects of chemotherapy treatment–Vincristine, a common chemotherapy medication and known neurotoxic agent, is used to treat acute lymphoblasticleukemia(19)–Vincristine causes axonal degeneration that progresses proximally in both the upper and lower extremities, resulting indecreased deep tendon reflexes and paresthesias in the fingers and toes with progressing symptoms including myalgia,paresis, sensory loss, motor weakness, and paralysis(20)–Bilateral peroneal nerve palsy can develop, causing equinocavus deformities(20)
pathogenesis: There is direct trauma or compression to the peroneal nerve at the fibular head, resulting in peripheral mononeuropathy(2)

Seddon’s nerve injury classification system(34)–Neurapraxia: although the axonal structure is still intact, a nerve injury (usually of a compression mechanism) has resultedin a conduction block and demyelination–Axonotmesis: a nerve injury involving a disruption of the continuity of axons while the connective tissue elements arestill intact–Neurotmesis: the most severe nerve injury, in which the entire nerve has been injured

Sunderland grading classification for nerve injury is more regularly used by surgeons to assist in determining treatment(34)–First degree: corresponds to neurapraxia above–Second degree: corresponds to axonotmesis above–Third, fourth, and fifth degree: injury to the endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium. Due to disruption in connectivetissue, regenerating neurons are misguided-Third degree: recovery often still occurs, but surgery may be indicated to release entrapped nerves-Fourth degree: regenerating nerve sprouts become entangled due to internal hemorrhage and fibrous tissue formation,neuroma develops in continuity with the axon. Minimal recovery is seen without surgery-Fifth degree: a complete discontinuation of the nerve has occurred and an end-bulb  neuroma forms. Minimal recovery isseen without surgery

The vasanervorum are small arteries that supply blood to the peripheral nerves. During a stretch/traction injury, elongationof a peripheral nerve over 15% might lead to rupture of the vasanervorum. This will eventually lead to ischemia, followedby numbness, tingling, and weakness(8)
risk factors: Jobs that involve extended periods of squatting or kneeling(1)
Diabetes mellitus, due to increased susceptibility to compression and ischemic injury(10)
No age-related  or race-related  risks are known
No sex differences in alignment of the lower leg, ankle, or foot that might increase risk(11)

overall contraindications precautions: See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: It is important to always respect the patient’s self-reported  level of pain

Although the peroneal nerve is most susceptible to injury at the knee, the nerve can also be injured at the hip and ankle due to tethered nerve fibers that are subject to traction injuries. Thus, the hip and ankle must be assessed in addition to the knee when evaluating a patient with a peroneal nerve injury(1)

Although foot drop is most likely due to a peroneal nerve injury, it can also be caused by other conditions that an evaluating clinician should rule out.(10) It is important to conduct a thorough evaluation, including a low-back  assessment. Patients can present with a foot drop due to an L5 radiculopathy (and not from a peroneal nerve injury) without low back or radicular symptoms.(10) See Rule out , below –Acute compartment syndrome is a medical emergency requiring immediate surgery. For more information,see Clinical Review…Compartment Syndrome, Acute ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708485. Chronic compartment syndrome is not a medical emergency. For more information, see Clinical Review…Compartment Syndrome, Chronic ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708750.

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Does the patient recall a specific initial injury, or was there a gradual onset? -How long have symptoms been present? Do the symptoms arise from any specific type of activity? -Has strength or sensation improved since the onset of symptoms?

course of treatment.medical management: Has the patient undergone any surgical or medical intervention to relieve symptoms? How has the condition responded to treatments? Nerve transfer(s) can be performed following severe nerve injury; however, this surgical procedure generally results in poor outcomes(26) Posterior tibial tendon transfer surgery has been shown to result in significant improvements in functional outcome measures as well as restoration of ankle dorsiflexion strength and ROM(35) This surgery has been applied in situations of foot drop following knee dislocation and CPNI
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications the clinician has prescribed, if any. Are they being taken? How have the patient’s symptoms responded to the prescribed medication? Vincristine, a common chemotherapy treatment, can result in peroneal nerve injury(19,20)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Electromyogram and nerve conduction tests; MRI to investigate location of nerve compression
Ultrasonography might be utilized to assess the integrity of the common peroneal nerve around the fibular head(10)
Radiographs and a CT scan may also be ordered to rule out pathology on or near the spinal cord
Standard knee protocols may not be sufficient to assess common peroneal nerve injuries(27)
More specific neural sequencing imaging studies with complete common peroneal nerve coverage were recommended for trial

Home remedies/complementary therapies:  Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack, OTC pain medications) or complementary therapies (e.g., acupuncture, herbal supplements) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. If so, what was the duration of therapy? What goals did the patient meet?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased). Do certain movements or activities aggravate or alleviate symptoms? Does exercise increase the patient’s symptoms? How long can the patient walk/jog/run prior to onset of symptoms? Does prolonged sitting or standing increase the patient’s symptoms? Does the patient prefer to sit cross-legged?
history of present illness.body chart: Body chart -Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -In the early stages, patients may report pain in lateral lower leg and dorsum of the foot(1)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -The patient might report paresthesias, pain, tenderness, or muscle weakness
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any. Patient may report night cramps
history of present illness.other symptoms: Other symptoms -Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., headaches, symptoms of visual or auditory impairment, vertigo, decreased balance, decreased coordination, dysarthria, loss of consciousness) -Patient might also report stubbing of the toes, slapping foot, and/or tripping when walking
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document the need for supplemental oxygen and parameters for oxygen use during rest/mobility. Does the patient smoke? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document any previous history of lower leg pain and/or paresthesias
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Document any medical conditions that may impair the patient’s mobility (e.g., arthritis, osteoporosis, neuropathy, central stenosis, traumatic brain injury). Document any medical conditions such as diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational activities, competitive sports, or hobbies? Does the patient currently work? If so, describe the job requirements. Does the patient drive or access public transportation?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What was the patient’s prior level of independence with ADLs? Does patient report any new limitations since the onset of the current injury? Is the patient currently using any assistive or adaptive equipment?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document the patient’s height, weight, body type, and BMI
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for current need, proper use, and condition of prescribed ambulatory assistive device or orthotic. Patient may be prescribed an ankle-foot  orthosis (AFO) to prevent tripping and falling
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess single-leg  balance with eyes closed and open and compare to unaffected side. Use the Berg Balance Scale (BBS) and/or Functional Reach Test to assess patient’s fall risk
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess bilateral distal pedal pulses  Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity –Perform a straight-leg  raise test with and without a peroneal nerve bias (hip flexion, plantarflexion, and inversion) –Note if testing elicits patient’s symptomsComplete a functional assessment as indicated. Use the Functional Independence Measure (FIM), Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, Timed Up and Down Stairs, or Timed Repetition Sit to Stand test for assessment of patient’s functional mobility
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess gait mechanics and note any asymmetry during swing and stance phases of gait. Note if the patient is ambulating with a foot drop, circumduction at the hip, increased hip and knee flexion (hip hiking or high stepping gait patterns), decreased step and stride length, decreased heel strike at initial contact, decreased eccentric control of the dorsiflexors causing foot “slapping,” the degree of foot drop(3) –Use the Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) to assess patient’s fall riskAssess bilateral lower extremity, lumbar, and sacral iliac joint mobility. Note if patient complains of increased pain or symptoms during joint mobility testing. Patient may have plantarflexion and inversion joint contracture
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess bilateral lower extremity and trunk strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) –Hip flexion (iliopsoas) – L1-3,  femoral nerve –Hip adduction – L3-4,  obturator nerve –Hip abduction – L4-S1,  superior gluteal nerve –Knee extension – L2-4,  femoral nerve –Knee flexion – L4-S1,  sciatic nerve –Plantar flexion – L5-S2,  tibial nerve –Plantar flexion with inversion – L5-S1,  tibial nerve –Plantar flexion with eversion – L5-S1,  superficial peroneal nerve –Dorsiflexion – L4, deep peroneal nerve –Dorsiflexion of great toe – L4-5,  deep peroneal nerve –Expect weakness in foot eversion (superficial peroneal nerve), ankle dorsiflexion (deep peroneal nerve), and big-toe dorsiflexion (deep peroneal nerve) –Is any weakness noted in any other muscle groups that might be indicative of another condition?
observation inspection palpation includi: Check for muscular atrophy, ecchymosis, edema, and ulcers(1)
Document the presence of any swelling; take lower extremity circumferential measurements as indicated
Assess wound and dressing if there is a history of trauma. Note any signs/symptoms of infection. Describe the wound size, location, color, and exudate
Assess for tenderness, especially at fibular head; residual pain after an ankle sprain may indicate entrapment of superficial peroneal nerve
Assess for skin irritation if the patient is wearing an AFO or brace
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for compensations in hip, knee, and ankle alignment
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM and flexibility of bilateral lower extremities and trunk; expect decreased active ROM in ankle and great-toe  dorsiflexion and foot eversion
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Perform a complete dermatomal sensory test and compare; two-point  discrimination may be more reliable –The common peroneal nerve provides cutaneous sensation to the lateral calf, whereas the superficial and deep peroneal nerves provide cutaneous sensation to the dorsum foot and the first web space (area between the first and second toes), respectively(1) –Assess bilateral lower extremity joint proprioception –Sensory signs and symptoms may be absent despite the presence of a peroneal nerve injury(10)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosiswhen tapping over the most superficial portion of the common peroneal nerve (i.e., fibular head and neck), any local tenderness or dysesthesia might be indicative of a peroneal nerve injury(10) –Use the Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire or the Foot and Ankle Questionnaire, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Is the patient alert and oriented x 4? Use the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) for further assessment of the patient’s cognition, as indicated. Can the patient focus and attend to a specific task?

contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Thermotherapy  contraindications(13) -Decreased circulation -Decreased sensation -Acute/subacute traumatic and inflammatory conditions -Skin infections -Impaired cognition or language barrier -Malignancy -Liniments -Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema -Heat rubs

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions(13) -Do not place electrodes near: -carotid bodies, cardiac pacemakers or implantable cardioverter defibrillators, phrenic nerve or urinary bladder stimulators, phrenic nerve, eyes, gonads -Osteomyelitis -Hemorrhage -Impaired sensation, mental status, communication -Cardiovascular disease -Malignancy -Dermatological conditions -Proximity of electromagnetic radiation -In pregnant women, near the pelvis, lumbar spine, hips, abdomen -In patients with stroke or seizures, near the neck -History of spontaneous abortion in pregnant women
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
An equinovarus foot deformity is a frequent complication when ankle dorsiflexion weakness is present. If a contracture develops, bracing can become intolerable, prompting surgical intervention(1)
Modify therapeutic exercises to allow for patient’s functional limitations (frailty, easy fatigability, poor balance/ coordination, increased fall risk)
The peroneal nerve is susceptible to iatrogenic injuries resulting from improperly applied ice packs(9) or below-knee  ankle splints(1)

If the injury involves complete laceration of the peroneal nerve, strengthening the denervated muscles will be ineffective. Hence, maintaining ankle dorsiflexion ROM becomes imperative in order to prevent contracture(1)
Consider surgical referral for nerve repair if paresis worsens during treatment or functional deficits persist 4 to 6 months after injury(12)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Painful nerve injury with reduced sensation and strength of lower leg and impaired mobility (walking, climbing stairs)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Sciatic nerve lesion (includes weakness of ankle plantar flexors)(10)  L5 radiculopathy (includes weakness of foot inverters)(10) Lumbosacralplexopathy(10) Multiple sclerosis(14) Anterior compartment syndrome (associated with night cramps)(36) Vascular disease CNS lesions Polyneuropathy Stroke Disease of muscle or neuromuscular junction Pelvic or retroperitoneal disease
prognosis: Patients with an incomplete peroneal nerve palsy will achieve full motor recovery, whereas < 40% of patients with a complete peroneal nerve palsy will be able to dorsiflex the ankle(25)

Nerve conduction studies can help determine prognosis. Nerve regeneration time is highly variable and may take months(34) –Neurapraxic injuries: up to 12 weeks –Axonotmesis: recovery time will vary depending on the location of the injury at a rate of 1 mm/day (cell body to the lesion) –Neurotmesis: recovery is poor and often requires surgery
Twothirds of a small study group (N = 27) experienced some limitations in walking ability, climbing stairs, and leisure activities for 3 years or more following peroneal nerve injury(2)

Recovery is highly variable after peroneal nerve damage. Patients with acute conduction block may recover in a few weeks, whereas permanent weakness and loss of sensation may follow demyelinating lesions

Among patients who sustain a knee dislocation, those with a partial peroneal nerve injury are more likely to regain antigravity ankle dorsiflexion strength in comparison to those with a complete peroneal nerve injury(18) –This United States research study included 27 patients with peroneal nerve injury who underwent multi-ligament  knee reconstruction and were followed for 6.3 years. The majority of patients (69%) regained antigravity ankle dorsiflexion(18) –Ankle dorsiflexion recovery is 80% likely to occur if the nerve is in continuity(24) –Multi-ligament  knee injuries with involvement of the posterolateral corner (PLC) are more likely to involve peroneal nerve injuries. In a case series, mid-substance  and fibular avulsion tears of the lateral collateral ligament (found in 96% of PLC injuries) were more likely to include peroneal nerve injury (28) -Patients with complete peroneal nerve palsy were less likely to regain function
There is generally a poor prognosis in peroneal nerve lesions from gunshot trauma or traction(7)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Occupational therapist for ADL training and evaluation of home or work barriers Podiatric surgeon for decompression of common peroneal nerve(15) Orthotist as indicated
treatment summary: The main objective is to alleviate any compression on the nerve. Orthotics and rehabilitation may be prescribed to manage and treat symptoms
Treatment consists of stretching, strengthening, balance/proprioceptive work, and functional training, in addition to orthotic prescription (as indicated)
Although peroneal nerve stimulators have been used for foot drop, they require a functioning peroneal nerve, so are not appropriate when a peroneal nerve injury is present(1)

In cases of posterior tibial tendon transfers for peroneal nerve injury and subsequent foot drop, physical therapy is initiated postoperatively(35) –If physical therapy was completed prior to the tendon transfer with a focus on the posterior tibialis tendon, recruitment and activation of the tendon transfer occurs early in the postoperative period  . Problem Goal Intervention Expected ProgressionHome Exercise Program Pain and paresthesia Reduce pain and paresthesiaPatient education _ Identify and educate patient on habitual causes of conduction block (see  Causes , above) _ _ Referral to surgeon or specialist as indicatedN/A Provide patient with written instructions regarding changes in habits. The use of padding when sleeping or during other offending activities may be necessary(3) Contractures and reduced ROMImprove ROM and reduce/prevent contracturePhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Use of heating modalities (in areas with normal sensation) to increase tissue extensibility(16) _ _ Manual therapy _ Perform manual stretching and joint mobilization for prevention of contractures due to denervation/weakness _ _ Therapeutic exercises _ Use of stretching techniques to prevent and treat the formation of muscle contractures(16)Progress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedProvide patient with proper education on stretching techniques, proper warm-up, and use of heating agents such as a hot pack  Impaired strength Improve strength Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ Chronic neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) improved axonal regeneration in an animal model of peroneal nerve injury. It is well established that functional NMES can help prevent disuse atrophy in denervated muscle(17) _ _ Manual therapy _ Apply proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation techniques to increase ankle strength _ _ Therapeutic exercises _ Strengthening can begin when MMT is greater than 3/5. During the early stages, do not rehabilitate the muscle to exhaustion(3) _Therapeutic exercises _ Progressive stretching and elastic-band strengthening exercises for the ankle and big toe dorsiflexorsProvide patient with home stretching and exercise program  Reduced balance/ proprioception and increased risk of fallsImprove balance/ proprioception and reduce risk of fallsTherapeutic exercises _ Exercises that challenge balance reactions, with a focus on the ankle region, by progressively testing the patient’s limits of stability(16) _ Perform double limb and single limb balance activities using level surfaces and then progress to uneven surfaces such as a foam wedge, Bosu ball, or mats. Challenge patient’s balance reactions and stability by having the patient perform activities with his or her eyes open and then closed and using upper extremities (e.g., toss/catch, dribble ball)Progress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedMay provide patient with simple exercises that can be done safely at home _ _ Implement fall prevention strategies at home Impaired gait and use of stairs; limited in recreational activitiesImprove gait and use of stairs; return to desired activitiesPrescription, application of devices and equipment _ AFO prescription as indicated. If only toe extensor weakness is present, stiff footwear may be all that is needed. If an isolated superficial peroneal nerve lesion is present, shoe orthosis with a lateral wedge will assist in improving gait(1) _ _ Functional training _ Gait training; stair negotiationProgress each unique patient as appropriate and indicatedIncorporate functional activities into home program as indicated .

improved balance proprioception: BBS, Functional Reach Test, single-leg  test
improved functional mobility, gait, and: Gait assessment, DGI, 6MWT, Oswestry Low Back Pain Disability Questionnaire, Foot and Ankle Questionnaire

maintenance or prevention: Identify and prevent habitual causes of conduction block (see Causes ); maintain independent therapeutic exercise program
Ensure fall-risk  precautions are followed if a patient is at risk for falls due to the presence of gait deficits
patient education: See “Common Peroneal Nerve Dysfunction” from MedlinePlus at https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/000791.htm

See “Drop Foot (aka Foot Drop)” from FootEducation.com at http://www.footeducation.com/page/drop-foot Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
